transcripts.text: Here's a debate between apologist Peter J. Williams and New Testament scholar Bart Ehrman about the reliability of the Gospels.

The ultimate answer is that the stories go back to something that happened in the life of Jesus.  People told the stories for a number of years.  There's nothing controversial about that.  In the book of Acts, people are telling stories the whole time without writing them down.  They're just telling the stories that they heard.  And so my view is a fairly standard view, which is that the stories were in circulation for many years.  before the Gospel writers produced their accounts.  Jesus and his disciples, of course, were Aramaic speakers in Galilee, a rural part of Galilee, and the Gospels are written in Greek.  And so these are accounts that were originally passed around probably in the native language of Palestine, but then are later written some decades later by Greek-speaking Christians.

So historians generally agree that the stories in the Gospels are not first-hand eyewitness accounts, as some fundamentalists argue, but are rather stories that may have ultimately originated with eyewitnesses, but which were passed around orally for years before being written down.

The way I'd put it is the Gospels don't come with dates on, but they do come with names on.  So, you know, if we just start with Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John, and there are no, you know, there aren't early manuscripts without those names on.  And I don't think it's likely that four gospels were each composed anonymously and then got these names on.  We can have some discussion about that because I think we're going to differ.

The gospels don't actually come with those names on them originally.  The authors didn't explicitly identify themselves, nor did they sign their work.  Early historians surmised who the authors were, and that's how they came to have the names they do.  Current historians doubt that they are reliably attributed.

So then you ask yourself the question, say with Mark and Luke, if it weren't for the Gospels of Mark and Luke, the names Mark and Luke would be sort of nobodies.  So I can't see a reason for people to stick those names on unless those are authentic.

I think the simplest explanation for why early scholars stuck those names on was because they believed them to be the actual names of the authors.  It doesn't follow from that, however, that they actually were the actual authors.  The names were not placed on the Gospels by the authors themselves.

I'd also say let's look at the internal signs within the Gospels and you start saying, What's the level of familiarity that these people have with the time and place they're writing about?  Do they know the geography?  When they just write about the Valley of Kidron, say, in the Gospel of John, I say, okay... check, you know, they know certain amounts about where things are when they're starting to use Aramaic words or specialist terms.  So the way Luke will talk about, he'll use dry measures and liquid measures, which are very Palestinian, the seer, the core, and the bath, you know, which he uses in chapters 13 and 16, you know.

Many apologists seem to have an all or nothing view of the reliability of Scripture.  They talk about it as though they think that if some details are correct, that's evidence that they all are, which doesn't follow at all.  And of course, extremists like Ken Ham will argue that if anything in the Bible is untrue, then the whole thing is worthless.  And also like Ken Ham, Williams seems to value testimony over physical evidence.

I mean, as in when you have people who are writing who say they were there at the time, you know, you get different numbers from what you get when you ask material archaeologists today.  I mean, isn't that fair?

Well, so in terms of population size, if you want to evaluate that, all you have to do is look at newspapers that report events that happen in our own day where you have photographs of the crowds.  Trump, for example, during his inauguration claimed that there were X number of people, millions of people, and the photograph showed it wasn't true.  Now, he was there.  So the fact that he was there doesn't show that he's right.

Archaeological estimates differ with contemporaneous accounts of population size, but are based on actual physical evidence, and literary population estimates clearly use a different method.  Since archaeological estimates are consistent with one another far more often than estimates given by contemporaneous writers, I think it's reasonable to hold the archaeological estimates to be more reliable.

They portray Jesus as predicting the fall of Jerusalem.  It seems to me to make sense that he predicted the fall of Jerusalem.  Now, you know, but that's where I do think one's belief in the supernatural or not is a factor.  This is probably a key point of difference between you and Constantine.  No, no, it's not at all.
Okay, go ahead.
I agree.  I always said I thought Jesus predicted the fall of Jerusalem.

William seems to think that if you don't believe in the supernatural, you are biased against the idea that Jesus predicted the fall of Jerusalem.  But there are lots of examples of people making accurate predictions, sometimes even baseless guesses, that ended up coming true.  Cities in the ancient world fell all the time, so this is an easy prediction to get right.  You don't have to believe that Jesus had magical powers to believe that he made this prediction.  But Peter Williams' favorite argument, it seems, is that the Gospels are reliable in what they say about Jesus because of all of the other little details that can be corroborated about the places mentioned at the time.  Here, Ehrman explains why that's fallacious reasoning.

So suppose in 2,000 years, there's a scholar who's heard that there's a story about a debate that took place on this radio show, Unbelievable, in Westminster.  And there's this American scholar, happens to be in England, And his name's Ehrman.  And he he he was in Wimbledon and he took a overground train to Vauxhall.  And then he walked across the Vauxhall Bridge and he came to and he was going to have this debate with somebody named Pete Williams, who actually came from Cambridge.  And and he'd heard the story and he wants to verify it.  So he goes on an archaeological dig, and he finds there was a place called London.  And it was a big place.  And there was a place southwest of it, Wimbledon.  And there was a train line that went to a place called Vauxhall.  And, oh, my God, he finds that there's somebody named Ehrman who actually had a place in Wimbledon.  And he digs further, and he digs in Cambridge.  He finds there's Pete Williamson.  But the story, the way the story continued was that before Ehrman got to the interview, There was a big explosion in Westminster that blew up the entire neighborhood, thousands of casualties because of a gas leak.  And he wants to see if that's true.  And what he finds is that every geographical marking is right.  There is a Wimbledon.  There is a Vauxhall.  There is a Westminster.  There is an Ehrman.  He can find all these facts.  Is he therefore right that there was a gas leak that led to an explosion that leveled Westminster?

So it doesn't much matter how many little details in the Gospels can be corroborated.  That is irrelevant with respect to the credibility of much else, especially the claims about Jesus doing miracles.  Each claim ought to be evaluated on its own merits and credibility.  There is, obviously, an inherent unreliability in stories passed around orally for years.  And this can be seen from the significant inconsistencies between the same stories in different Gospels.  Next, Ehrman explains one of the weirdest Bible contradictions.

The death of Judas Iscariot.  So Judas, in Mark, Luke, and John, Judas, nothing happens to him after, he just disappears.  In Matthew's Gospel, Judas hangs himself.  And what happens is he goes, he feels remorse about what he's done, he's betrayed Jesus for 30 pieces of silver, he tries to return the 30 pieces, the high priest won't take it, so he throws them down in the temple and goes off and hangs himself.  And the priests then say, oh, we've got these 30 pieces of silver.  We can't put them back in the treasury because it's blood money.  It's used to betray blood.  And so they go off and they buy a field, and it's called the field of blood because it's purchased the blood money after Judas has hanged himself.  Luke also wrote the book of Acts, as we were saying.  And in chapter 1, there's a second account of Judas' death.  In this account, what happens is there's nothing about Judas hanging himself.  Nothing about the priest buying the field.  In this account, Judas goes and buys the field before he dies, and he doesn't hang himself.  He somehow falls head first, and his intestines break open and bleed all over the ground.  And so the people in Jerusalem start calling this a field of blood because Judas bled all over it.

There are two contradictions in these stories.  One is that the priests buy the field in one story and Judas buys it in another.  And the other contradiction is that Judas hangs himself in one story and falls headfirst and explodes, for some reason, in the other.  I've heard an apologist, I'm sorry I wish I could remember who, who tried to explain the first contradiction by saying that Judas technically bought the field in both stories, because in the story in which the priests buy it, they buy it with the blood money that Judas returned to them, so that's technically the same as Judas buying it.  This is sophistry.  If you go to a barber and get a haircut you don't like, and the barber agreed to return your money, then you went and bought lunch with it, it would be very misleading to say that the barber bought you lunch.  If you said that, you wouldn't mean it literally, and you'd probably then explain exactly what you meant.  You wouldn't leave it to somebody else telling the same story to fill in that detail.  Yet that's what some apologists want us to think the New Testament is doing.  We're supposed to believe that one book says that Judas bought the field, and the other fills in the more literal details of what was meant by that.  This is another example of apologists expecting us to believe that the perfect infallible word of God was scribed by people with the communication skills of a wombat with an inner ear infection.

I think it's really interesting that we got these two accounts and Bart mentioned two things as he went through the accounting acts.  One is he used the word somehow.  that Judas somehow, and the phrases, became headlong.  Well, that to me is just crying out for some more details.

Yes, isn't it weird that a divine account of someone's death makes it sound like they just did a somersault and exploded?  You'd think that even a mildly competent author, let alone an all-knowing and infallible one, would understand that such an account would leave the reader a bit confused.  It's rather counterintuitive to think that such an author would put some more explanatory details in an entirely different book of the Bible.

We need to explain.  We need some sort of like vertical elevation.  Oh, Matthew has vertical elevation because he has to hang himself.  So I'd want to say that.  The account in Acts is crying out for a bit more.  And the other issue we got is his intestines.  How on earth do his intestines start bursting forth?  I mean, like, that wouldn't normally happen if you just fall.  So in other words, I'd want to say, you know, that makes a lot of sense.
So how did it happen?
So how did it happen?  I'd want to say, I think you can put the two together.  Probably the data are underdetermined, as in that is I can't.  there would be multiple scenarios that would fit those.
Give me one.
Let's say someone hangs and then the rope snaps and, you know, after they're dead and their entrails burst out.  I'm not a medic on that, but, you know.
Yes, okay.  So let me ask this.  If somebody's hanging and the rope snaps, that's happened before, how do they fall?
Down.
Yes, they fall down.
Do they fall headfirst?
Well, it depends what they think.
Does it depend?
Yes, it does.  It depends what they're hanging over.
What do you mean?
Well, I mean, if you're hanging over something and there's a rock forward and you're going to trip on it and you go head forward, I mean, like these things can happen.  I don't know.
These things can happen.  I don't know is apparently the height of Christian textual hermeneutics.
It sounds like we're doing CSI here, you know, crime scene investigation.  I just think the data is underdetermined.
Let me just say this.  Yeah, it's underdetermined.  So to reconcile it, you have to come up with a completely implausible scenario to reconcile it.

That's typical of not only attempts to explain inconsistencies in the Bible, but also attempts to reconcile creationism with physical evidence.  Apologists have to come up with scenarios that are far less plausible than the idea that what's written in scripture is simply not true.  Even in the story of Judas' death, it seems like a perfectly plausible explanation.  that the account says that Judas fell head first is mistaken.  Maybe he hanged himself, his body fell feet first out of the noose after a while, and the body hit the ground and bled all over it.  That seems pretty plausible to me.  There are probably more and bigger errors in the account than just that one detail.  However, those who believe in biblical inerrancy wouldn't concede that even a detail as tiny as Judas fell headfirst could be mistaken.
Do I believe all scripture is true?  Yes.
With no mistakes of any kind anywhere.
I believe that God didn't make any mistakes of any kind.
I don't think God makes mistakes either.  But I'm not talking about God.  But you don't believe in God.
Exactly.

Both some religious people and some irreligious people seem to think that in order to genuinely follow a particular religion, you have to believe that the religion's scripture is inerrant.  I don't see why that's necessarily the case.  If you believe in and worship the God of Christianity, you're a Christian even if you believe that the Bible was written by fallible human beings who got some things wrong about what that God revealed to them.  Saying the Bible got something wrong is not the same thing as saying God got something wrong, even if you believe in a God.

So I think you'd be pretty skeptical if I proposed a miracle to you because it would be inconsistent with your worldview.  In the same way, I would say I've got lots of positive reasons for thinking that Scripture is miraculous, and it all builds up to this climax with Jesus, and there's prophecy beforehand, and he seems to do lots of remarkable things.  And so I'm trying to make sense of things together, as I think you would do.
I have no problem with that.  But what I'd like is to be acknowledged that that's doing theology.  It's not doing history.

If you want to honestly examine the Bible from an objective historical perspective, you have to put aside your doctrinal commitments.  That doesn't mean you have to deny them.  It only means that you have to abstain from incorporating them into a historical interpretation.

History is not done by coming at it with a theological presupposition about what had to happen.  You look at the evidence, and then you see, does the evidence move me that way or not?  You don't approach it by saying, this has to be right because God said it.
But are you saying that no one who holds to a theological view, let's say of the authority of Scripture, can therefore do proper history as well?
I'm saying that if you're going to do proper history, you cannot allow your presuppositions about God to affect the outcome.

And I would say I've never tried to claim that I am doing history.  I often would want to make a distinction between the sorts of things that go on in history departments and what I believe rationally you should trust.
Because apparently the sorts of things that go on in history departments are not exactly what rationally you should trust.

I think you've got several different things going on here.  One is a history department will never lose out.  Well, it tends to be weighted towards not believing something.  So when, you know.  When G.R.  Driver first heard Sir Godfrey Driver, a great Hebrew professor, that Dead Sea Scrolls had been discovered, he said, you know, probably not genuine, and it turned out to be genuine, but his reputation didn't suffer damage.  When, you know, Hugh Trevor Roper said the Hitler Diaries are probably genuine, and they turned out not to be, his reputation really took a hit.  So there is a way in which I think it's a bit like hedge fund managing.  You know, that history departments can stack things so that, you know, skepticism is more favored.  That, again, is different from what you do as a jury.
No, it isn't.  A jury presumes innocence, which means that it treats the charges against the defendant with skepticism.
When you're looking at someone, that's also different from what you do as a friend.  if someone comes to you and says to you that they're a victim and you say, I trust you.

Yeah, but the folks who wrote the Gospels are not my friends.  I don't know them.  I don't know much more about them other than the fact that they wrote those documents.  Why should I treat those claims the same as the claims of a friend whom I know personally who tells me some crime has happened to them?

When you get to the Gospel of John, Jesus no longer preaches about the kingdom of God.  He doesn't tell people to repent in preparation for the coming of the kingdom of God.  He doesn't say that you will be destroyed when the kingdom of God comes.  The way he talks is different now.  And rather than talking principally about God and the coming kingdom, he talks about himself.  who he is.  And so you get some of the most famous sayings of Jesus.
I am the way, the truth, and the life.

The way, the truth, and the life.  No one comes to the Father but by me.  I am the light of the world.  I am the bread of life.  The good shepherd.  Before Abraham was, I am.  I and the Father are one.  You get all of these claims, many of which have a component of divine identity connected with him.  He's claiming to be a divine being.  That's crystal clear in the narrative of John, because Jesus will say, I and the Father are one, and the Jews will pick up stones to stone him to death for committing blasphemy.  You don't have those stories in the earliest Gospels.  And it's striking, and you have to explain, if Jesus did go around calling himself a divine being, You know, if that really happened, as John says.  John says it happened.  And it's the major teaching of Jesus in John.  If that's what happened, why isn't it in Mark or Q?  Is it that they didn't think it was important to report that part of Jesus' teachings?  Or a more plausible explanation.  for most people, for most critical scholars, a more plausible explanation is that over time, the Christians' understanding of Jesus changed, and they started seeing him as less of just a human messiah and more as some kind of divine being over time.

It's in the Gospel of John that Jesus is portrayed as not just having been bodily born in Bethlehem, but also as having existed with God the Father since the beginning of the universe.  If that's the case, and if it's something Jesus himself said, then it is rather weird that it is left out of the earliest Gospels.  You'd think that kind of thing would be worth mentioning.  Since it's not, I don't think it's that much of a stretch to infer that it was a later interpretation rather than something that comes directly from Jesus himself.  to everyone who helps me out on patreon you're a big help.  thanks so much.
